color_semantics.green: High (or positive) exemplar for the row’s statistic
color_semantics.orange: Low (or negative) exemplar for the row’s statistic

legend_rules.default_rule: Green icon denotes the 'high' side and orange icon denotes the 'low' side for each statistic.

exceptions.note: Crime is phrased so that the 'green/high' exemplar corresponds to lower crime (safer), while the orange/low exemplar corresponds to higher crime.

raw_strings.highest_countries_values: Highest Intake: United States (~3,750 cal), Mexico (~3,200 cal)
raw_strings.lowest_countries_values: Lowest Intake: Haiti (~2,200 cal), Nicaragua (~2,450 cal)
Highest Crime: Honduras (high homicide), El Salvador (gang violence)
Lowest Access: Haiti (<50%), Honduras (limited rural access)
Lowest Rates: Haiti (>40% unemployment), Nicaragua (high informal sector)
Lowest Engagement: Haiti (low formal volunteering), El Salvador (limited data)

featurettes.title: Fighting the Flames - Wildfires in North America
featurettes.body_text:
Wildfires are powerful, fast-spreading fires that burn through forests and grasslands. They happen often in places like California or western Canada, where hot, dry weather turns trees and plants into easy fuel. As Earth’s climate warms, droughts become more common, making it easier for sparks—from lightning or a campfire left unattended—to grow into a raging blaze.

When wildfires strike, they can destroy homes, harm wildlife, and fill the air with thick smoke. Firefighters use helicopters, planes, and special tools to contain the flames. Communities plan ahead with fire safety rules, and everyone can help by following local guidelines and using fire responsibly. Together, we can protect people, animals, and our forests from going up in smoke.

featurettes.title: Suburban Life – America’s Unique Neighborhoods
featurettes.body_text:
In the United States, many families choose to live in suburbs—neighborhoods filled with single-family homes, green lawns, and quiet streets just outside big cities. After World War II, more people bought cars and wanted more space. Suburbs grew quickly, and soon millions of Americans were commuting to work from their cozy houses.

In other countries, more people stay close to downtown, often using trains or buses to get around. In American suburbs, most people rely on cars to reach stores, schools, and offices. While suburbs offer peace and privacy, they can lead to more traffic, more gasoline use, and more pollution. Still, suburbs remain a big part of how many Americans live and shape their everyday lives.

featurettes.title: America’s Natural Wealth—Resources and Industry
featurettes.body_text:
From fertile farmland to underground minerals, the United States holds a treasure chest of natural resources. Rich soils grow abundant crops like wheat and corn. Deep below the surface, oil, gas, and minerals power factories and fuel cars. Skilled workers turn these raw materials into everything from smartphones to skyscrapers.

Over time, these resources helped the U.S. grow into a strong economy, creating jobs and building cities. Farmers feed the nation and the world, miners provide metals for tools and machines, and engineers guide energy from deep underground to light up our homes. By understanding and protecting these resources, people can keep the country thriving for generations.

featurettes.title: Roads, Rails, and Rivers – Connecting America
featurettes.body_text:
Look at a map of North America and you’ll see a web of highways, train tracks, and rivers tying distant places together. The Interstate Highway System lets you drive across the country, while railroads carry heavy loads like coal and grain. Rivers and canals allow ships to move goods cheaply and efficiently, and airplanes link people to far-off cities in just a few hours.

These transportation networks bring fresh produce to your grocery store, deliver packages to your doorstep, and connect friends and families. Without them, the economy would slow down, and everyday life would be harder. Whether by road, rail, water, or air, these routes keep America’s heart beating and its people moving forward.

supplemental_stats_for_app.label: Fluoridated community water systems (United States)
supplemental_stats_for_app.value_display: ≈74% of the population served by community water systems receives fluoridated water
supplemental_stats_for_app.why_it_matters: Connects to 'Access To Clean Drinking Water' by highlighting a distinctive public-health water treatment practice.

source.section: Access to Clean Drinking Water → Oddball Statistic: Fluoridated Water

supplemental_stats_for_app.label: Medical debt (United States)
supplemental_stats_for_app.value_display: ≈17% of individuals affected by medical debt
supplemental_stats_for_app.why_it_matters: Adds nuance to 'Access To Healthcare' by separating availability of care from affordability.

source.section: % Population with Access to Healthcare Services → Oddball Statistic: Medical Debt

supplemental_stats_for_app.label: Gig economy participation (United States)
supplemental_stats_for_app.value_display: ≈36% of the workforce engaged in freelance/contract work (as of 2020)
supplemental_stats_for_app.why_it_matters: Provides context for 'Employment Rates' by noting the role of non-traditional work arrangements.

source.section: Employment Rate or Economic Participation Rate → Oddball Statistic: Gig Economy

validation_and_todos.description: Physical print dimensions (inches) and bleed/safe margins are not explicitly provided; only pixel canvas size was inferred from the proof PDF.
Greenland appears on the proof map but is not present in the 'stats map palette' sheet. Added as #FFFFFF based on the proof; confirm intended treatment (exclude, gray, or link to Denmark).

Infographics/mini-maps referenced in featurettes do not include finalized data tables in the provided files (no graphs-stuff doc). If charts are to be data-driven, provide datasets and units for wildfire risk, population density, resource locations, and freight by mode.

Some core stats use mixed or qualitative definitions (e.g., 'Crime Rate' described via 'high homicide' and 'gang violence'; 'Employment Rate' low exemplar includes unemployment and informal sector). Consider normalizing definitions/units for consistency across continents.
Several linked image sources appear to be commercial or media outlets (e.g., Alamy, iStock, CNBC). Confirm licensing/usage rights or replace with appropriately licensed imagery.
No separate vector/source file for the main continent map was provided (only the poster proof). For downstream use, provide the editable map asset (SVG/AI) and label layer data.
